title: Treaty of Apamea; Seleucids expelled from Asia Minor 188–133 Attalid rule in Asia Minor 171–168 Third Macedonian War 170–168 Campaigns of Antiochus IV in Egypt

container-title: translated in the Oxford World’s Classics series by Robin Waterfield, Plutarch: Hellenistic Lives
note: The rich Egyptian papyrological documentation is brought to life by Naphtali Lewis, Greeks in Ptolemaic Egypt (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1986).
title: The travels of Clearchus of Soli were first reconstructed by the French scholar Louis Robert, the greatest modern historian of antiquity; Robert’s ‘De Delphes à l’Oxus: inscriptions grecques nouvelles de la Bactriane’
416–57, remains perhaps the single most inspiring article ever written on the Hellenistic Age. Johann Gustav Droysen’s conception of the ‘Hellenistic’ is discussed by Arnaldo Momigliano
Droysen between Greeks and Jews’
Studies on Modern Scholarship (Berkeley and Los
The most accessible (and entertaining) narrative sources for the period are Plutarch’s biographies of Hellenistic rulers
A good selection of Hellenistic inscriptions in translation

note: The most insightful treatment of Alexander’s early successors is Mary Renault’s novel Funeral Games
title: Frank Walbank’s The Hellenistic World
is a reliable and readable guide to Hellenistic history, now supplemented by the essays collected in
A Companion to the Hellenistic World
Graham Shipley’s The Greek World After Alexander, 323–30
is also recommended. The conquest of Asia by Alexander of Macedon (334–323 ) comes to life in the hands of Pierre Briant, Alexander the Great and his Empire: A Short Introduction
The Seleucid kingdom is the subject of a fine recent monograph by Paul Kosmin, The Land of the Elephant Kings
while the Ptolemaic dynasty of Egypt is best approached through Günther Hölbl, A History of the Ptolemaic Empire

note: The rise of Rome is unflinchingly narrated in the collected essays of Peter Derow, Rome, Polybius, & the East (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014).
title: The Adulis inscription of Ptolemy III is discussed in Glen Bowersock’s The Throne of Adulis
The poems of C. P. Cavafy—an excellent introduction to Hellenistic culture—are translated into English in the Oxford World’s Classics series by Evangelos Sachperoglou
Cavafy: The Collected Poems

note: The classic analysis of Hellenistic royal images, in sculpture and on coins, is R. R. R. Smith, Hellenistic Royal Portraits (Oxford:
title: CHAPTER 3: DEMETRIUS THE BESIEGER AND HELLENISTIC KINGSHIP The centrality of military conquest to Hellenistic royal ideology is emphasized by Michel Austin, ‘Hellenistic Kings, war and the economy’
For the Hellenistic king at war, consult Angelos Chaniotis, War in the Hellenistic World
The most helpful starting point for Hellenistic ruler-worship is Simon Price’s Rituals and Power: The Roman Imperial Cult in Asia Minor
The inscription recording the establishment of a Seleucid ruler-cult at Aegae can be found in Supplementum Epigraphicum Graecum 59

author.particle: scholarship in Hellenistic Alexandria can be found in

container-title: The Oxford Handbook of Engineering and Technology in the Classical World
Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society
note: provides an excellent introduction to Greek and Roman technology, in which Hellenistic innovations play a major role; a selection of translated texts can be found in G. L. Irby-Massie and P. T. Keyser, Greek Science of the Hellenistic Era: A Sourcebook (London and New York: Routledge, 2003).
title: History of Classical Scholarship from the Beginnings to the End of the Hellenistic Age
Ptolemaic Alexandria
The best short account of the Alexandrian Library is that of R
Alexandria: Library of Dreams’
The surviving fragments of Eratosthenes’ Geography are translated and discussed by D. Roller, Eratosthenes’ Geography

container-title: The Therapy of Desire: Theory and Practice in Hellenistic Ethics
title: Ludic Proof: Greek Mathematics and the Alexandrian Aesthetic
is a lively study of the ‘interface’ between Hellenistic mathematics and poetry. Stoic and Epicurean philosophy receive a sympathetic hearing from M
There are good photographs of Aï Khanoum and its major artefacts in the British Museum exhibition catalogue Afghanistan: Crossroads of the Ancient World
the best introduction to the history of the site is now Rachel Mairs, The Hellenistic Far East

container-title: For the Villa of the Papyri, see Carol C. Mattusch, The Villa dei Papiri at Herculaneum: Life and Afterlife of a Sculpture Collection
note: and David Sider, The Library of the Villa dei Papiri at Herculaneum (Los Angeles: The J. Paul Getty Museum, 2005).
title: Iromois’ dedication to the Oxus can be found in Georges Rougemont, Inscriptions grecques d’Iran et d’Asie centrale

The Greek historian Arrian describes Nearchus’ exploration of the northern shores of the Indian Ocean in his Indica, translated in the Oxford World’s Classics series by Martin Hammond, Arrian: Alexander the Great, the Anabasis and the Indica
Posidonius’ account of the travels of Eudoxus of Cyzicus is preserved in Strabo’s Geography (2.3.4), translated for the Loeb Classical Library by H
Strabo: Geography, Books 1–2
The decree for Protogenes of Olbia is translated by Michel Austin, The Hellenistic World from Alexander to the Roman Conquest
The best short introduction to Priene in English is Frank Rumscheid’s well-illustrated guidebook, Priene: A Guide to the ‘Pompeii of Asia Minor

container-title: Epigraphical Approaches to the Post-Classical Polis
note: Clarke’s day-trip to Priene in 1870 is recounted by C. T. Newton, ‘On an Inedited Tetradrachm of Orophernes II’, Numismatic Chronicle n.s. xi

John Ma discusses the ‘statue habit’ at Priene, and the changes that it brought to the city’s public spaces, in his magnificent Statues and Cities: Honorific Portraits and Civic Identity in the Further Reading
title: The wider geographic context of the city’s history is sketched in my own The Maeander Valley: A Historical Geography from Antiquity to Byzantium
All of the Greek inscriptions discussed in this chapter are published with German translations in W
Die Inschriften von Priene
the decrees honouring Sotas and conferring ruler-cult on Lysimachus are translated into English by Stanley M. Burstein, The Hellenistic Age from the Battle of Ipsos to the Death of Cleopatra VII
and 17. Alexander’s edict to Priene is discussed by Susan Sherwin-White, ‘Ancient Archives: the Edict of Alexander to Priene, a Reappraisal
69–89, and in my own ‘Alexander, Priene, and Naulochon’
Hellenistic World
The rise of the great civic benefactors of the later Hellenistic period is traced by Philippe Gauthier, Les cités grecques et leurs bienfaiteurs
